name: Tecentriq approval on safer ground after FDA panel vote
introduction: While the US regulator has been taking a hard look at Accelerated Approvals which lack confirmatory data, Tecentriq (atezolizumab) appears set to retain its approval in breast cancer at least.
content:
While the US regulator has been taking a hard look at Accelerated Approvals which lack confirmatory data, Tecentriq (atezolizumab) appears set to retain its approval in breast cancer at least.

The Oncologic Drugs Advisory Committee (ODAC) voted to maintain the decision on the basis of the clinically-meaningful benefit shown by the IMpassion130 study.

This is despite data from the IMpassion131 study failing to meet its primary endpoint on progression-free survival.

The combination of chemo plus Tecentriq, a checkpoint blocker from Swiss cancer giant Roche (ROG: SIX), has been marketed in this indication since early 2019.

Chief medical officer Levi Garraway explained: “People with triple-negative breast cancer have few treatment options, which is why today's committee decision to recognise the importance of this Tecentriq combination is significant.”

He added: “We are grateful to the FDA and ODAC for the open dialogue and look forward to continued collaboration to improve the lives of people with breast cancer.”

While the opinion of the FDA’s scientific panel is not binding, the agency usually opts to go along with the outcome.

On Wednesday the panel will move the conversation on to another of Tecentriq’s Accelerated Approvals, this time as a treatment for people with locally-advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma.

Whereas the therapy was approved on the basis of Phase II data for this patient population, a subsequent Phase III study missed its primary endpoint.
